text: But do thou for me, O GOD the Lord, for thy name's sake: because thy mercy is good, deliver thou me.
text_kjv: But do thou for me, O GOD the Lord, for thy name's sake: because thy mercy is good, deliver thou me.
text_niv: But you, O Sovereign Lord,deal well with me for your name’s sake;out of the goodness of your love, deliver me.
text_esv: But you, O GOD my Lord, deal on my behalf for your name's sake; because your steadfast love is good, deliver me!
text_nlt: But deal well with me, O Sovereign LORD,for the sake of your own reputation!Rescue mebecause you are so faithful and good.
text_msg: Oh, God, my Lord, step in;work a miracle for me—you can do it!Get me out of here—your love is so great!—
text_nasb: But You, O GOD, the Lord, deal [kindly] with me for Your name's sake; Because Your lovingkindness is good, deliver me;
context: Psalm 109 is an imprecatory psalm, meaning it contains curses or strong condemnations against the psalmist's enemies. This type of psalm reflects a deeply felt sense of injustice and a plea to God for vindication. In ancient Israelite culture, justice was seen as a divine prerogative, and individuals often turned to God to right wrongs when human systems failed. The expression of intense anger and calls for retribution, while unsettling to modern readers, were understood as a way to affirm God's sovereignty and his role as the ultimate judge. David, traditionally attributed as the author, likely faced significant opposition and betrayal. The cultural context of the Old Testament allowed for a more direct and even violent expression of emotions, particularly when seeking justice. The concept of corporate personality, where an individual's actions reflected on their family or group, also influences the severity of the curses. Understanding this historical background is crucial to interpreting the psalm's content. The psalmist believed his reputation and well-being were directly tied to God's reputation. A failure of God to act would be seen as a failure of God's justice and faithfulness in the eyes of the psalmist's community and enemies alike. The psalmist is calling on God to act not only for his personal deliverance but also to uphold God's own character and commitment to justice within the covenant relationship.
meaning: Verse 21 shifts from the harsh pronouncements against enemies to a direct appeal for divine intervention. The phrase "But do thou for me, O GOD the Lord," underscores the psalmist's utter dependence on God's power and sovereignty. The invocation of "GOD the Lord" (Adonai Yahweh) emphasizes both God's supreme authority (Adonai) and his covenant name (Yahweh), highlighting the psalmist's reliance on God's faithfulness to his promises. The plea "for thy name's sake" is a critical element. It reveals that the psalmist's primary concern is not merely personal vindication but the glory and honor of God. He recognizes that his deliverance will reflect positively on God's character and demonstrate his power to the world. The phrase "because thy mercy is good" provides the theological basis for the psalmist's hope. He appeals not to his own righteousness or merit but to God's inherent goodness and compassion (chesed, in Hebrew). Chesed represents God's steadfast love, grace, and loyalty, a foundational attribute of God's character throughout the Old Testament. The psalmist believes that God's chesed will compel him to act on behalf of the oppressed and deliver the needy. The verse encapsulates the core of biblical faith: trusting in God's character, seeking his glory, and relying on his mercy for salvation. It shows that God’s deliverance is deeply connected with His reputation.
application: In modern life, Psalm 109:21 offers several practical applications. First, it reminds us to prioritize God's glory in our prayers. When facing adversity, our focus should extend beyond personal comfort and encompass a desire for God to be glorified through our circumstances. Are we asking God to work not just for *our* good, but for *His* glory? Second, the verse encourages us to ground our hope in God's character. Rather than relying on our own strength or abilities, we can confidently approach God, knowing that his mercy and love are unfailing. Recognizing and clinging to the truth of God's goodness is paramount when we feel overwhelmed by injustice or suffering. Meditate on the attributes of God – His love, His mercy, His faithfulness. Third, we can use this verse as a model for prayer in times of need. The psalmist's direct and honest appeal to God provides a framework for expressing our own dependence and vulnerability. Don’t be afraid to be transparent with God about your struggles, knowing that He welcomes authentic prayers. Fourth, consider how you can advocate for justice and mercy in your community. Just as the psalmist sought divine intervention, we can also work to alleviate suffering and promote righteousness in our own sphere of influence. This can involve supporting organizations that fight injustice, advocating for marginalized communities, or simply showing compassion to those in need. By embracing God's mercy, we are called to be agents of mercy in the world. Fifth, when wronged, we should pray for the heart of God toward the wrongdoer, seeking His justice and mercy for all involved. This doesn't negate the reality of consequences, but it does allow us to release bitterness and trust God's ultimate judgment.
prayer: O GOD the Lord, I come before you, recognizing my dependence on your grace and power. I am surrounded by challenges, and I feel the weight of injustice pressing upon me. But I lift my eyes to you, the sovereign ruler of all. I ask that you act on my behalf, not just for my own sake, but for the sake of your holy name. Let your glory be revealed in my deliverance. I know that your mercy is good, overflowing and unending. I cast myself upon your chesed, trusting in your steadfast love and faithfulness. Strengthen my heart to endure, give me wisdom to navigate these trials, and fill me with your peace that surpasses all understanding. Help me to reflect your love and grace to those around me, even those who may cause me pain. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: In the ancient world, a person's name represented their reputation and character. For God, his name reflects his very being. By asking God to act for his name's sake, the psalmist is appealing to God's own integrity and reputation. He trusts that God will act in a way that upholds his honor and demonstrates his power.
faqs.question: Q1: Why does the psalmist focus so much on 'God's name'?

faqs.answer: Psalm 109 reflects an Old Testament understanding of justice and retribution. While uncomfortable for modern readers, it highlights the intensity of the psalmist's suffering. Jesus' teachings emphasize forgiveness and love of enemies, representing a higher standard. Christians are called to strive for this higher standard, while acknowledging the historical context of the Old Testament.
faqs.question: Q2: How can I reconcile the imprecatory nature of Psalm 109 with Jesus' teachings on love and forgiveness?

faqs.answer: The Hebrew word for mercy, *chesed*, encompasses love, kindness, grace, and faithfulness. To say that God's mercy is good is to affirm that his love is constant, reliable, and available to those who seek him. It is a declaration of God's unwavering commitment to his people and his character.
faqs.question: Q3: What does it mean that 'God's mercy is good'?

faqs.answer: This verse serves as a pivotal shift in Psalm 109. It transitions from harsh condemnations of the psalmist's enemies to a desperate plea for God's intervention. While the psalm begins with a focus on justice and retribution, verse 21 highlights the psalmist's ultimate reliance on God's mercy and grace.
faqs.question: Q4: How does this verse relate to the rest of Psalm 109?

faqs.answer: Absolutely. The psalmist's appeal is based on God's character, not his own merit. The verse emphasizes that God's mercy is 'good,' meaning it's freely given and available to all who call upon him, regardless of their perceived worthiness. It is a plea based on faith, not performance.
faqs.question: Q5: Can I pray this verse even if I don't feel like I deserve God's help?
